content: I quit I can't do the full-time job the family and the channel all at the same
time anymore it's too much I have to stop
hey guys welcome back to another episode of black magic crafts now don't don't
worry relax I did quit but it doesn't mean what you might think it means it's
good news and we'll get to that in a minute
with my home renovation project still in full swing but getting there getting
there don't worry it's getting there I haven't had any time at my workbench
to build any terrine or paint any minis so I'm taking this opportunity to do
another Q&A video I haven't done one of these for over a year I really like
doing them and it's a great way for me to get through a lot of the stuff that
you guys ask that I don't answer in video so we're gonna do that
today but before we do that I'm gonna make a few channel announcements that
actually answer a bunch of the questions that came up the first thing is quitting
well for those of you following the channel for a very long time who saw my
2017 update you know that this channel is a huge time resource sink it takes up
so much of my time for the past two years I've been working a full-time job
putting in tons and tons of hours into this channel all while trying to balance
family life having no evenings no weekends no nothing for almost two years
and it got to be too much and I couldn't do it anymore and I had to stop
something luckily I didn't have to stop the channel I stopped my job that's
right I am officially a full-time content creator on YouTube it's pretty
pretty crazy actually this has been going on for a little while and I
haven't made an announcement to the general public
only my patreon supporters have known this it's been about three months since
I resigned from my job at first I kind of did a slow exit out to help them out
where I was still sticking around one to two days a week to kind of get them set
up with a replacement and all that but for the past while I've been basically
full-time then several weeks ago I pulled the plug completely and I've been
giving this channel my full time resources and that's why longtime
viewers will notice that over the past three months my build videos have
grown a bit in complexity I've been able to do things that took a bit more time
I've been putting a lot more time into editing and learning about video
production and all that other good stuff to try to improve the videos and it's
paying off the channel isn't is growing at an explosive rate it's really really
crazy and I have absolutely no fears that this whole crazy venture will pan
out I'm doing just fine however that's because of the help of you guys
especially people on patreon and the people using those Amazon links paying
for the like donating through the templates all that has come together to
allow me to be a full-time content creator on YouTube and dedicate my life
to making these videos for the community pretty crazy right the other thing I
wanted to address a few people asked about this is how my wife is doing
because when I did my 2017 update I talked about her illness she has Crohn's
she was off of work it was really really bad I'm very happy to say that she is
doing significantly better the infusion drugs are seem to be working she's in
remission and she is back at work so that is phenomenal I mean it's not a
disease that gets cured it's just a disease that you get under control
but currently it is under control and she's doing very very well and I
appreciate those of you who remembered that and asked about it when I pulled
you guys for questions that means a lot I got a lot of questions and I boiled
them down to about 60 so I'm gonna try to power through them pretty quickly I
chose the ones that were what I thought were the most useful to answer the ones
that I thought would be the most informative and the most fun there was a
lot of overlap so some questions are getting combined a lot of the questions
had to do with my job and carpentry and what Mike what I really do for a living
and like I said I just quit my job but my history of employment just so you
guys know is I went to school for carpentry but there's a lot of
misconceptions about me being a carpenter I wasn't like a fine
woodworker I went to school for carpentry then I got into the renovation
business and for over a decade I renovated houses doing custom kitchens
and bathrooms and I did every trade involved
start to finish so I did the carpentry I did minor electrical plumbing dry wall
painting flooring finish carpentry tile set a lot of tile did a lot of masonry
work I did it all and that's what I did for a very long time and then last year
I took a job at a prestigious design build firm where I was a construction
manager and I was overseeing huge construction projects both residential
renovations as well as commercial stuff I mean we're talking I was renovating
kitchens that were like half a million dollar kitchens so that's what I was
doing up until recently I just resigned for that from that now I'm full-time
youtuber so when I say I'm a carpenter I went to school for carpentry I did a lot
of carpentry but I was involved in many trades in general that had to do with
renovations so that answers a bunch of your question because there was a lot
related to that there was also a lot of questions that were really basic and I
want to remind you guys that I do have a basic series for beginners I will put a
link up there and in the video description you guys if you're new you
should check that out one question I want to answer that didn't come up here
but I get asked it every few days in YouTube comments is why don't you stream
your games we really want to see you streaming your games I would love to but
there's a couple reasons I don't what you don't realize to do it of a good
quality it requires several cameras microphones and a crew and those are
resources and cost that the channel isn't quite ready to take on yet I'm not
willing to just put up an iPhone and have a crappy sounding game streaming
through the internet I'd rather do nothing than do one that's of a crappy
quality maybe one day I'll get there but not yet you want to help me out try out
patreon and maybe one day I'll be able to stream the games all right so now
let's get down to your real nitty gritty questions I'll try to power through them
as quickly as I can while still giving informative answers here we go how many
of each type and size of tile do you think is a good place starter set versus
I deal amount this is a question comes up quite a bit this is going to depend
on the per ton you ever these are different but the way I think
about it is look at your gaming surface how big is the area that you play on is
it 2 feet by 4 feet is it 3 feet by 3 feet
whatever that sizes make enough tiles to completely fill that space maybe some
extras in terms of turns and whatever because you're not gonna need more
really then fills that whole space personally my 3 by 3 tiles my basic
dungeon tiles I only have like a dozen of them plus maybe 6
there's no four six by six tiles and two 12 by 12 and then all my extra kind of
other style tiles and that's enough for me and just build more as you need it
what is the most used touring piece you personally use gaming besides tiles
that's easy that's these pillars these pillars get used all the freaking time
and I'll put a link where you can watch the tutorial of how to build those I
also get a lot of use out of these little stones they are little styrofoam
stone pillars that get used as a placeholder for all sorts of things they
are fantastic what building terrain or terrain pieces
are essential for a good DM kit what are some staple pieces that every crafter
should add to their collection obviously the dungeon tiles pillars and rocks just
make some rocks you make different kinds I got a video on these ones these will
get used all the time some basic trees or bushes are very very handy and
dungeon stackers make a set of dungeon stackers links up there and down there
because those can be used for pretty much anything and then you can just
build more as you need it what would you say is the best project for a beginners
first campaign if you're just starting out crafting I think making the basic
dungeon tiles is the best place to start get you familiar with cutting foam and
painting and that sort of thing if you were starting out as a crafting DM today
what would you do differently and why what I would do differently is take it
easy on the amount of stuff I'm putting on
the table in my early games when I started out I went full-blown and the
first couple sessions I had these crazy elaborate setups I spent months and
months planning for my first game that set a tone that was not easily easy to
maintain for her over the next several months of gaming I couldn't keep up to
that so I would say don't go too overboard at the beginning and don't set
up you know your players to expect that every single time just ease into it use
some terrain use some battle mats use some theater of the mind use a mix that
way there won't be this expectation that every five minutes you'll have some
crazy new diorama on your table what would you consider the most overlooked
but useful piece of equipment that you use for crafting that is my carpenter's
t-square my small t-square it's over there I don't want to get up and grab it
I'll put a link it's in my essential equipment store that t-square is so
important for doing layouts and getting perfect 90-degree angles it's a perfect
metallic straight edge for cutting everybody should have a small
carpenter's t-square not just for crafting but just in life it's a it's a
good tool what crafting skills you gained through terrain crafting were you
able to transfer to your real life and how and that's the interesting question
because usually it's my day job real life stuff that I transferred to
crafting but what have I done in the reverse and actually there was a few
times doing renovations where I had to do really delicate touch-ups like
cabinets or furniture or wood or whatever that had damage on it and I
needed it to color match and do very fine detailed touch-ups I more than once
went home to my workbench and grabbed some fine detail brushes and some paints
and mixed colors and was able to do on-site repairs using the skills I
learned painting miniatures what do you do with minis that are too big for the
one-inch base but the Monster Manual needs them to be that size so basically
you got a monster that's tatted to take up a one-inch base but the model is too
big well here's the thing I just put it on a bigger base I ignore
the Monster Manual I ignore the stats because 90% of the monsters I use anyway
I homebrew or I alter I never use a monster straight out of the book
never I always customize it to my own game and my own needs so don't worry
about it just put it on a bigger base that suits the model and hey the stats
are it's a bigger sized creature who cares what three creations are you most
proud of well my child my home no in terms of crafting I would say my guard
tower is one that I am really proud of I'll put a link there's a video on that
the dark chapel sinister Cathedral put a link to that and I think my cadaver
collector mini I'm really really proud of that one and I'll again put a link
for that build I'm really happy with that one what's up with brushes I kind
of just grab a brush and use it but what's the difference between the
different brushes and how do I know what I should be using is there a dummy proof
just use this brush 90% of the time answer ignoring mini painting because
that's a whole other thing and I'm not an expert on that but for terrain
building just you're right just grab whatever works 90% of the time you're
gonna be one wanting to use a flat chisel brush to cover large areas and
for dry brushing use a big flat chisel brush I honestly don't don't overthink
it it's just terrain how thin should a foam
sheet be to be able to bend it into a curve how do you cut it thin enough I
mean it depends on the foam usually even foam core which is about 3/16 of an inch
thick you can bend on the curve it depends how sharp you want that curve
for something really sharp you want to be shaving down the foam to like a
sixteenth of an inch or a couple millimeters something like that and to
cut foam that thin you need no way around it a hot wire table and a high
rip fence so I use my props on and my shifting lens guider Pro what crafting
skills of yours have you derived from carpentry that the average crafter
should learn basic measurement and layout skills understanding
how to layout a square it's pretty incredible most people don't know how to
layout a square you should be able to on a blank piece of paper in any
orientation right in the middle be able to layout a perfect square with right
angles it's a basic carpentry layout 101 straight line perfect 90-degree angle
measure off make the square I have a video that talks about that in more
detail the basics of cutting a square and I think every crafter should know
that basic skill just basic geometry what was your introduction to D&D what
was your age group of friends etc I haven't been playing D&D that long I've
only been playing two and a half years something like that
a friend of mine wanted to get into it started wanted to start playing it we
were playing Magic the Gathering a lot together him and his wife wanted to do
it she decided to run some games I said sure why not I played a couple games as
a player I was hooked I wanted to DM and as soon as I made the
decision to DM I knew I wanted to start building cool things because I've always
had an interest in model making and that sort of thing so here we are haven't
been doing it though that long favorite Tim bit let me tell you about Tim bits
Tim bits are waste of time give me a proper donut I don't want that little
donut hole ball I want a real doughnut especially because the best doughnut is
a Boston cream or a jam Buster you need the full donut to get the yummy gooey
insides what's your preferred way to seal Prime and paint cork I don't use
cork I don't like cork as a crafting material it is way too prone to warping
and it's brittle I just I just don't like it I mean you can seal it with glue
or Mod Podge but it's gonna warp and I just don't use it next page how much
time per week do you spend crafting well that obviously varies in the past when I
was working full time you know I was spending
10-12 hours a week crafting most of the time I spent was editing videos and all
the other stuff related channels but about 10 to 12 hours a week
crafting now I spend significantly more it can be 20 to 30 hours a week when I'm
doing more involved builds for the channel and videos and then also doing
some just stuff for myself on the side I might spend 20 hours in the week
building something for the channel and then another 10 just painting miniatures
to unwind for myself besides an upgraded fence for the Prok town what if any
other jigs or attachments do you use most definitely the circle cutter that
is number 2 there is also the shape tool I don't remember what it's actually
called it allows you to cut hexagons and different shapes like that I don't use
it very often but it's very handy aside from the proc song add-ons the other
shifting lines things that I use the most are the cork board which I reviewed
and the paint bottle holder because it's holding my paint 24/7 do you still use
the green stuff rollers to do textures which ones do you use the most I use
them once in a while not as much as before because now I have a little bit
more time I'm not as pressed I don't have to do speed builds all the time so
I do prefer to do the individual bricks but once in a while it's still really
handy absolutely the brick texture one hands down is the most useful the normal
size don't get the smaller size one it's kind of too small for foam and actually
I use them a lot more now for their intended purpose on green stuff on
miniature basis where do you go to find inspiration for campaigns nowhere
specifically I guess I just draw on the various kind of subconscious inspiration
from all the movies and TV shows that I watch regularly or have watched
throughout the years one place I do actively seek inspiration as I will go
on to drive through RPG and I will look at all the indie titles and I'll just
download a bunch of three or cheap one shot short adventures read them over
take a few things that I like and kind of mash them together and
than my own do you do any dungeon tiles with traps on the bottom flip the tile
over and boom pit trap no I don't do flip tiles I don't do two-sided tiles
just for my own reasons I do have trap tiles that I have built
on the channel before and they are 3x3 trap tiles that replace the tile rather
than flipping one over again link if you want to check out how to make those
what has the Blackmagic craft and journey been like this thus far ups and
downs pros and cons and would you do anything differently if you could do it
all over a short recap of the overall pillow pal experience that's a
thoughtful question it's been a crazy two years I started the channel on a
whim just for the hell of it and I really got into it after a couple months
I realized it was serious and I started treating it seriously I started treating
it like a business I started working really hard the last year and a half has
been really really challenging it's been a huge strain on my family my wife going
through serious illness having a toddler having the channel working a stressful
job it's been hard probably the last year and a half the most difficult years
in my life on top of that there was a lot of death in the family my grandpa
passed away and on the day I was at my grandpa's funeral I got a text saying my
best friend had committed suicide so there's some Downers for the this video
so needless to say the last a year and a half has been very very challenging but
the way I dealt with that was by working my ass off because that's how I deal
with everything I work really hard and I just go 110 percent and that's what I've
done and now this year this past three months have been the best three months
of my entire life because I'm living the dream doing this full-time that's
because I worked so friggin hard and persevered through so much difficulty I
didn't miss a single episode I never took a break no even when I was going
through the illness and the deaths and the kit I never stopped got a video
every week worked my butt off and now I'm reaping the Lord rewards so that's
how you deal with life work hard you'll get there what is your favorite
thing to do or watch so you can unwind after a long gaming session or a hard
long build or work day or maybe what's most importantly why I used to watch a
lot of TV shows there's a lot of series that I was into into you obviously Game
of Thrones Vikings those sort of shows tons of Netflix drama stranger things
whatever since we had a kid and I started this channel we have not really
watched much movies and TV whatsoever 95% of my viewing is YouTube I unwind in
bed at the end of each day watching YouTube some of my favorite things to
watch have nothing to do with crafting or this hobby although I do watch you
know all my fellowship brothers and sisters but I tend to watch a lot of non
D&D stuff I really enjoy good mythical morning with rhett and Link they are my
YouTube heroes and I love their content I like watching a lot of food shows like
Bon Appetit and sorted food I love watching tested because I love Adam
Savage and the way he approaches things so yeah I watch a lot of YouTube ever
considered attempting to model some world of warcraft or inner structures
nope because I've never played World of Warcraft never seen the movie don't know
anything about it and I'm not interested sorry do you find that your knowledge of
carpentry helps you design your builds absolutely 100% without a doubt my son
and some of my friends are game but how do I get started just by the DN book and
go from there or do I need to write down my own story I already play war games so
models and scenery are no problem first of all you don't need to make your own
story you can if you want it's personal preference and you don't even need to
buy all the books by the if you want to play fifth edition you want to play D&D
just buy the starter box it has a short adventure in it that's already
pre-planned for you it even has pre generated character sheets and a basic
rule set so nobody needs to buy the players handbooks on the Monster Manual
anything like that that one $30 box 30 bucks or whatever it is is all you need
to get started and if you like it you can grow and buy more things as you get
into it is there going to be a tutorial of making the water board as seen in the
long bolt video or was there already one and I somehow missed it
I'm sorry guys I promised that video when I made it and I still have not made
it mostly just because I just haven't felt like making another one it's a bit
of a messy build but basically I'll sum it up for you here piece of blue
styrofoam thick at least an inch thick so it's sturdy take a drywall joint
compound add a bunch of water add some PVA glue mix it up till it's thin enough
to spread over the whole board then take a wet paint roller and roll it over that
texture to give the then first row the NAP from the roller gives it that
texture of little waves let that dry spray paint the whole thing blew dry
brush all the little tiny ridges very lightly with white to look like the
crest of waves and then spray the whole thing in a high gloss varnish and you're
done and that's how I made that water board maybe one day I'll make another
one but I just for whatever reason I'm not interested in making another one how
can you adjust the length of terrain to not be huge like in storm Kings Thunder
I can't figure out how to make a map playable and not be ten feet long well
that's because you're trying to make the whole map don't make the whole map just
do a little bit at a time just place on the board the part that the players are
in my gaming surface is only 3x3 so everything fits in the 3x3 space put
down the tiles put down the scenery put down whatever for that particular part
and then when they move on put the next treat it like a side-scrolling video
game well a top scrolling I guess why have you started crafting the reason I
started crafting is that previously I was a musician and all my time was
dedicated to producing and recording music we had a baby I couldn't be loud
in the studio anymore I couldn't be traveling for music so I needed to stick
around home and I needed a quiet hobby like I said earlier my friends got me
into D&D and so I started doing that it was a great hobby because it was quiet
and I could just put it down and walk away when the wife and kid needed me and
then I got so addicted took over my whole life I know it takes a long time
to build such things and life goes on while we're at it so how do you manage
your fam a hobby and job well like I said it was
really hard over the past couple years I'm very good at time management being a
construction manager taught me how to manage time very very well being a
contractor taught me how to think smart with my builds knowing I have to do this
now so that it dries and is ready for tomorrow to save me some time you got to
really think about that stuff ahead of time so they can be super super
efficient that's why a lot of the stuff I do focuses on efficiency luckily now I
have a little bit more time to spare if you are running a homebrew campaign how
do you start what do you need to make a good night of adventure I typically run
homebrew adventures my advice is don't think about the huge world and all the
politics and religions and all that just think small when I started in my
homebrew world I started in a village first session in a village all the
characters are from that village and myself and no one else knew anything
about the greater world and my world built as they explored in each time I
was prepping for session I expanded on the world a little bit think small think
micro not macro because micro is the most important thing for good metagaming
how often do you play D&D and how long are your gaming sessions well my groups
that I DM for shoots to play about every three weeks but over the summer that
falls apart and we play like every four to six weeks people in you know Canadian
summers you gotta take advantage of them people spend the weekend at the cabins
they got projects going on all sorts of things there's a lot of holidays and
whatnot so we don't play very often but in the winter when it's dark and cold
and miserable we play about every three weeks when we can I also am a player in
a game that follows about the same schedule how long are your gaming
sessions is another question on here somewhere
and we used to play like for four to six hours and we realized that people were
burning out and getting tired now we shoot for like three hour games and I
find that those are perfect that keeps everybody excited on their toes three
hours is about perfect maybe about four hours of hanging out to account for all
the other stuff like eating and drinking bathroom breaks and whatnot but about
three hours of game play is ideal for my group at least for a layout like
Ravenloft Castle Ravenloft how might you go about creating thin walls to match
the dimensions given in cursive strawed cardboard I don't make walls and I
typically don't use pre-generated maps with my tiles I use the negative space
in between them that 1-inch space of negative space to represent shared walls
doesn't work for a lot of pre-made maps and for something like a castle
Ravenloft I would just be doing one room at a time with tiles or doing bigger
areas on a battle map I think that's the way to go do you use a 3d printer if so
what brand I do not however I've become increasingly more interested in them
because they are getting very cost-effective I will get one and I'm
not gonna get a filament one I'm going to get a resin 3d printer and you know I
don't remember the name of it I've hand I researched it I know which one is one
day I'll get a 3d printer what piece of equipment do you wish you could buy
there's not actually a lot I will get a 3d printer eventually like it's not a
matter of cost it's just I don't have time to dedicate to learning that new
aspect of the Hobby right now I will at some point but in a perfect world I
would love a big huge shop that has one of those industrial C&C Foam cutters
that would be pretty nifty what do you believe is the most common
mistake new crafters make one I think in terms of crafting DMS I think it's over
doing it and trying to build too much for their games but just in general
crafting it's melting styrofoam with using aerosol that you should not use
and not testing on foam and also just getting things that are warped and then
going why did my thing work it's like well if you put wet things on cardboard
or glue that shrinks it's gonna warp learn about those materials and what
causes warping would you ever do any conventions yeah I would I would like to
do I think as the channel grows that's something that's gonna happen in the
future it's a little bit more difficult for me being in Canada because most of
the big conventions are in the States and it's actually a little bit
complicated to travel as a guest or a presenter with visas and whatnot and I
don't have one day well it's not not yet maybe soon maybe I think not sure I'm
gonna go to Gen Con have you ever made considered making a DM screen to look
like tabletop scenery absolutely not I really dislike those
big massive DM screens that look like capsules I think they are a huge
distraction a visual they're in the way visually I think it's pointless I don't
like it if you want to do it cool but you won't see one of those on my table
how do you prioritize your projects build what I need for the game will it
make the game play better or is it really needed to play out the scenario
then make that first if it's just something fun that you want to do that
gets made last do you make your own music for the videos no I don't the
early videos with the old intro and intro music I just I did compose that
myself but lately I I don't I don't have time and I'm not interested I just I
don't feel like making music these days I do pay a lot of money for the music
that I use now over the last several months you may have noticed an
improvement on the music I used to use the same Kevin MacLeod music that a
hundred other channels use and I was so sick of hearing them so now I actually
pay for expensive music licenses and get higher quality music for my videos
because that's important to me ever thought about making a discord channel
I've thought about it quite a bit mostly for as a patreon reward but to be
honest I've never used discord I don't know much about it I'm an old man some
of these new things confuse me I still don't fully understand how to use
Twitter I'm good at YouTube but I'm good at Facebook but discord
I don't really fully understand what it is yeah I'll probably do one at some
point after buying a 4x8 sheet of pink foam board how do you break it down into
manageable pieces I don't know why this is people have such a hard time with it
you just cut it take the 4x8 sheet go with a parking lot take a knife cut it
snap it throw it in your car in the trunk it's just cut it and if you mean
getting it down to smaller pieces to use on your procs on because you don't want
to be using massive pieces straightedge and an Olfa knife how does one get clean
cuts with thicker foam like one-inch pink foam well I have a video on how to
get clean cuts in foam when it gets to thicker foam and you want nice cuts that
are plumb you got to use a hot wire table there is other ways that are
really convoluted and complicated that I'd really hot wire table I'm sorry I
wish I could tell you there was a better way once a piece is on the table how
is it there I just finished the Sinister chapel video and it doesn't exactly have
a huge floor plan how long did the party explore stay in near this place how many
set pieces are on the table at any time a piece like the Sinister chapel
actually for me when I first used it ended up on the table for the whole
night of gameplayer most of it and that's because there was the encounters
leading up to it so it was there as an exterior and then they got inside and
you know spent maybe an hour of gameplay inside as a big encounter and
exploration took place I've used that piece multiple times anytime I need a
church or a chapel but that's why I say don't make your buildings and stuff too
complicated don't spend too much time on them because know you're not gonna get a
hundred hours a game play out of one thing it's gonna get sporadic use it's
gonna be on the table for a couple hours so put in an amount of work that you
think is appropriate for something that's gonna see that much play what
game setting do you use when you run D&D well for the longest time I use my own
homebrew setting started a new campaign we're about three sessions in and I have
been running that one in Forgotten Realms but it's taking place up in the
north in the damara just felt like using some Forgotten Realms stuff for a while
how do you avoid disappearing detail when giving them models coats of paint I
always have a loss of sharp edges and find gaps but if I had water the paint
doesn't cover well I have the same problem with Mod Podge you have to think
like for miniatures you have to thin your paint and yes the water will make
it not cover as well thin multiple coats for terrain I don't really water stuff
down I don't water down the Mod Podge I just try to apply it evenly and the
answer is carving with stronger detail make your detail stronger to account for
that loss what is the worst experience you've had DMing so Nicky if you're
watching this story I gotta apologize in advance it involves you
I ran the sunless Citadel I felt like running a pre published thing and turns
out didn't know this ahead of time one of my players is actually DM to that
adventure years previously and that really ruined it for me that put me in a
bad place as a DM it shouldn't have there are ways that you as a player can
play something you've already run or played
through before but didn't work out that way
it kept coming up in the game of oh I know what's here or this wasn't like
this when I did it so that was really defeating and it was a real bummer I did
massively change it I completely changed the whole adventure the second half of
it I made a hundred percent unique but it still became a problem of the player
saying well that's not how it was when I did it it's like well I changed it
because you played this before and I was overall not a good experience
so DMS if that happens try to pivot and adjust and players if you find yourself
at a table and you've played that adventure before or you've run it before
be a good player and don't let it get in the way don't make it a big deal act as
though you haven't played through it before try not to use too much made of
knowledge as a crafting DM how do you compensate for the downtime between
setups like when apart party goes into any room that you need to set up or just
tell everyone to leave for five minutes while you set up one it's it's planning
